Twitchett |editor2= |title=The Cambridge History of China Volume 3: Sui and T'ang China, 589–906 AD, Part One |url= |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1979 |isbn=9780521214469}} * {{Cite journal|url=http://www.shin-ibs.edu/documents/pwj-new/new10/02Sugiyama.pdf |title=Honganji in the Muromachi-Sengoku Period: Taking Up the Sword and its Consequences |last=Sugiyama |first=Shigeki J. |date=1994 |journal=Pacific World |doi= |pmid= |access-date= |publisher=[[Institute of Buddhist Studies]] |issue=10 |volume=2 |location=Berkeley, California |pages=56–74 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429165235/http://www.shin-ibs.edu/documents/pwj-new/new10/02Sugiyama.pdf |archivedate=29 April 2014 |df= }} *{{Citation |author1=John Whitney Hall |author2=Takeshi Toyoda |title=Japan in the Muromachi Age|year=1977|location=Los Angeles, Berkley, London|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=0-520-02888-0}} * {{cite news |author=Morning Tribune Staff |title=Yellow Sand Cult to be suppressed by Japanese |volume=1 |issue=154 |url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/morningtribune19360730-1.2.46 |work=Morning Tribune |location=[[Beijing|Peiping]] |date= 30 July 1936 |access-date=3 May 2018 |page=9 |ref=harv }} * {{cite news |author=The China Monthly Review Staff |title="Yellow Sand" Society Suppressed by Japanese in Demilitarized Zone |volume=77 |issue= |url= |work=The China Monthly Review |location=[[Custom House, Shanghai]] |date= 20 August 1936 |access-date= |page=473 |ref=harv }} *{{cite book |last = Perry |first = Elizabeth J.|authorlink =Elizabeth J. Perry |title= Rebels and Revolutionaries in North China, 1845-1945 |url= |date= 1980 |publisher= [[Stanford University Press]] |location= [[Stanford, California]] |isbn= |ref=harv}} * {{Cite journal |url = |last1= Xing |first1= Hansan |last2= Li |first2= Guoqiang |title = YUDONG HUANGDAO HUI QIYI |trans-title= The uprising of the Huangdao Hui in east Henan in 1911 |date = 1991 |journal = Shixue Yuekan (Journal of Historical Science)|doi = |pmid = |publisher = |issue = |volume = 5 |location = |pages = 64–69 |language = Chinese |ref = harv}} * {{cite book |last = Tai |first = Hsüan-chih |title= The Red Spears, 1916-1949 |url= |date= 1985 |publisher= Centre for Chinese Studies Publications, [[University of Michigan]] |location= [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] |isbn= |ref=harv}}

revision.text:
'''Martin Šmíd''' was a fictitious [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] university student, who was supposedly killed in the police attack on the November 17, 1989 student demonstration in Prague that launched Czechoslovakia's [[Velvet Revolution]].<ref name="Bilefsky">Dan Bilefsky, [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/18/world/europe/18czech.html "Velvet Revolution’s Roots Obscure 20 Years Later,"] ''New York Times,'' 17 November 2009.</ref> The rumour of Šmíd's death was spread by Drahomíra Dražská, a porter at a student dormitory in the city's Troja district. The dissident [[Charter 77]] activist Petr Uhl believed her story and passed it along to [[Radio Free Europe]], the [[BBC]] and [[Voice of America]], who broadcast it.<ref name=Fall>Sebestyen (2010), ''Revolution 1989: The Fall of the Soviet Empire'', p. 370-371</ref> The news of a student's death shocked many, and the rumour is thought to have contributed to the fall of the Communist regime in Czechoslovakia.
The Martin Šmíd in question was allegedly a student of the Faculty of Mathematics and Physics at [[Charles University]]. Two students with that name attended the school at the time, both in their second year at the university, but nothing happened to either of them on November 17. One did not attend the student demonstration, and the other left it just before the police attack. After the story spread across the country, the public reaction was one of outrage. The government showed the two Martin Šmíds and interviewed one of them on television, but people did not believe their assertion that the story was fictitious. Massive demonstrations began across the weekend and the government responded by arresting Uhl for "spreading false rumours".<ref name=Fall/>
Drahomíra Dražská's actions, and her motivation for them, have never been fully made clear. The most likely explanation is that she invented the story of Šmíd's death,<ref name="dezinformace">Závěrečná zpráva vyšetřovací komise Federálního shromáždění pro objasnění událostí 17. listopadu 1989, část III. 5) - Desinformace o údajném úmrtí studenta Šmída, [cit. 2009-10-21]. [http://www.psp.cz/eknih/1990fs/tisky/t1236_06.htm Available online.]</ref> and Dražská herself has on several occasions reaffirmed this claim.<ref name="drazska">Drahomíra Dražská: Strůjkyně zprávy o mrtvém Šmídovi promluvila. [http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/72859-drahomira-drazska-strujkyne-zpravy-o-mrtvem-smidovi-promluvila/ Available online.]</ref> Following the [[Velvet Revolution]], a [[conspiracy theory]] began to spread that the incident had been a secret police operation. According to journalist Victor Sebestyen, the StB "faked the 'death' of Martin Šmíd in order to create a groundswell of popular anger that would remove General Secretary [[Miloš Jakeš|Jakeš]] and other hardliners, and replace them with [[Mikhail Gorbachev|Gorbachev]]-type reformers."<ref name=Fall/> Sebestyen maintained that Ludvík Zifčák, a junior StB agent who had infiltrated the student movement, fell down and played dead during the November 17 demonstrations in [[Wenceslas Square]] and that Dražská, whom Sebestyen also believed to be an StB agent, then passed on to Uhl the story that "Šmíd" had been killed.<ref name=Fall/>
However, an investigation by a committee of the Czechoslovak parliament found no evidence of these claims, and Dražská's involvement with the StB was found highly unlikely.<ref name=dezinformace/> Furthermore, following the events of November 17, Zifčák continued his undercover work, casting doubts on his role as Martin Šmíd since the operation would be compromised had he been recognized.<ref name=dezinformace/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Smid, Martin}} [[Category:Velvet Revolution]] [[Category:Death hoaxes]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:Nonexistent people used in hoaxes]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox building | name = Martyred Intellectuals Memorial | native_name = {{lang|bn|বুদ্ধিজীবি স্মৃতি সৌধ}} | image = Martyr's intellectual monument at Rayerbazar.jpg | caption = Martyred Intellectuals Memorial | building_type = Public Monument | architectural_style = | structural_system = | address = [[Rayerbazar]], [[Mohammadpur Thana]] | location = [[Dhaka]], Bangladesh | architect = Farid Uddin Ahmed
Md Jami-al-Shafi | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | coordinates = |roof ={{convert|58|ft|m|0}} |start_date = 1996 |completion_date = 1999 | awards = | references = | status = completed | height = }} '''Martyred Intellectuals Memorial''' ({{lang-bn|বুদ্ধিজীবি স্মৃতি সৌধ}}) is a memorial built in memory of the [[1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals|martyred intellectuals]] of the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]]. The memorial is located at Rayerbazar, [[Mohammadpur Thana]] in [[Dhaka]].{{cite book |last=Ahmed |first=Syed Shabbir |year=2012 |chapter=Mohammadpur Thana (Dhaka Metropolitan) |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Mohammadpur_Thana_%28Dhaka_Metropolitan%29 |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} The memorial was designed by architect Farid U Ahmed and Jami Al Shafi.{{cite book |last=Amin |first=Md. Shahidul |year=2012 |chapter=Badhya Bhumi Smriti Soudha |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Badhya_Bhumi_Smriti_Soudha |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}[http://www.thedailystar.net/magazine/2003/12/02/coverstory.htm Star Magazine][http://www.mediabangladesh.net/articles.details.php?recordID=10 Seven Icons of History at Dhaka] The initial proposal for a memorial at Rayer Bazar was brought forward by Projonmo 71 (organisation of the children of the martyrs of liberation war), who also laid a temporary foundation stone in 1991. ==History of Intellectual Massacre== During the entire duration of the Bangladesh Liberation War of 1971, a large number of teachers, doctors, engineers, poets and writers were systematically massacred by the [[Pakistan Army]] and their local collaborators, most notably the alleged [[Islamism|Islamist]] militia groups [[Al-Badr (East Pakistan)|Al-Badr]] and [[Al-Shams (Bangladesh)|Al-Shams]]. The largest number of assassinations took place on 14 December 1971, only two days before the surrender of the Pakistan Army to the joint forces of the [[Indian army]] and [[Mukti bahini]]. [[File:Intelectual Martyrs Memorial, Mirpur.jpg|right|thumb|Foundation plaque of the memorial, Mirpur, Dhaka.]] On the night of 14 December 1971, over 200 of East Pakistan's intellectuals including professors, journalists, doctors, artists, engineers, and writers were rounded up in Dhaka. They were taken blindfolded to torture cells in Mirpur, Mohammadpur, Nakhalpara, Rajarbagh and other locations in different sections of the city. They were later executed en masse, most notably at Rayerbazar and Mirpur. In memory of the martyred intellectuals, 14 December is mourned in Bangladesh as ''Shaheed Buddhijibi Dibosh'' ("Day of the Martyred Intellectuals"). Even after the official ending of the war on 16 December, there were reports of hostile fire from the armed Pakistani soldiers and their collaborators. In one such incident, filmmaker [[Zahir Raihan]] was killed on 30 January 1972 in Mirpur, allegedly by the armed Beharis of Mirpur. The number of intellectuals killed is estimated as: educationist 991, journalist 13, doctor 49, lawyer 42, others (litterateur, artist and engineer) 16.{{cite book |last=Khan |first=Muazzam Hussain |year=2012 |chapter=Killing of Intellectuals |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Killing_of_Intellectuals |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} Intellectuals who were killed between 25 March and 16 December 1971 in different parts of the country included [[Govinda Chandra Dev]] (Philosopher, Professor at DU), [[Munier Chowdhury]] (Litterateur, dramatist, Professor at DU), [[Mufazzal Haider Chaudhury]] (Litterateur, Professor at DU), [[Anwar Pasha]] (Litterateur, Professor at DU), [[Mohammed Fazle Rabbee]] (cardiologist), Alim Chowdhury (ophthalmologist), [[Shahidullah Kaisar]] (journalist), Nizamuddin Ahmed (Reporter), [[Selina Parvin]] (reporter), [[Altaf Mahmud]] (lyricist and musician), Hobibur Rahman (Professor of Mathematics, RU), Sukhranjan Somaddar (Professor of Sanskrit, RU), Mir Abdul Quaiyum (Professor of Psychology, RU), [[Dhirendranath Datta]] (politician), [[Ranadaprasad Saha]] (philanthropist), Lt. Col. Moazzem Hossain (ex-soldier), Mamun Mahmood (Police Officer), and many others.[http://www.newagebd.com/2005/dec/15/murdered/murdered.html No count of the nation’s intellectual loss] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201162513/http://www.newagebd.com/2005/dec/15/murdered/murdered.html |date=1 December 2010 }}", ''The New Age'' ==Design and Construction of the Memorial== In 1993, the Government of Bangladesh decided to erect a memorial at the site. The Ministry of Housing and Works Department and the Institute of Architects Bangladesh jointly organised a national level architectural competition for the design of the memorial "Badhya Bhumi Smriti Soudha". Out of 22 entries the jurors selected the design proposal of Architect Farid Uddin Ahmed and Architect Md Jami-al-Shafi. Public Works Department was responsible for the implementation of the project and its completion took about three years (1996 to 1999). ==Design Significance of Martyred Intellectual Memorial== The main element of the monument is approxiamtley 17.7 m high, 0.9 m thick and 115.8 m long curved brick wall, representing the original brickfield of Rayer Bazar where the dead bodies were found. The wall is broken at the two ends, representing grief and sorrow. A square window at the south-west side of the wall permits visitor's view to reach the sky behind, that also scale down the wall. In front of the curved wall is a still water body from which rises a black granite column, which represents grief."Badhya Bhumi Smriti Soudho'" Banglapedia. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Category:Martyred Intellectuals Memorial}} * [http://www.bangladeshtourism.gov.bd/historical_place1.php Historical places], National Tourism Organisation, Govt. of Bangladesh. {{Dhakaplaces}} {{Bangladesh Liberation War}} [[Category:Aftermath of the Bangladesh Liberation War]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Dhaka]] [[Category:National symbols of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Martyrs' monuments and memorials]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | image = | imagesize = | | name = Michael Cawood Green | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|4|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Natal Province|Natal]], South Africa | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Academic, writer | nationality =South African | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = }} '''Michael Cawood Green''' (born 10 April 1954) is a South African born academic and writer.
As a researcher he is most noted for his monograph, ''Novel Histories'' which explores the uses of history in [[South African fiction]]. He is the author of two works of historical fiction, ''Sinking: A Verse Novella'' about the 1964 [[Blyvooruitzicht]] sinkhole disaster, and ''For the Sake of Silence'' about the [[Trappists]] in South Africa.
Michael Green's fiction forms part of a 'new wave' of writing (see also [[Zakes Mda]], [[Ivan Vladislavic]], [[J. M. Coetzee]]) which explores the altered landscape of [[Post-apartheid South Africa]]. His work, as noted critic Leon de Kock puts it, "...speaks to the muteness of history, ... that ruptures the silence of time past, and further, ...talks so very eloquently about those who would not speak at all..."[https://web.archive.org/web/20110714083149/http://michaelcawoodgreen.com/index_files/Page967.htm](Review: Leon de Kok, Sunday Times online, 15 June 2008)
Michael Green is currently Professor in English and Creative Writing at [[Northumbria University]].
== ''For The Sake of Silence'' == Winner of the 2009 Olive Schreiner Prize [https://archive.is/20130421225355/http://news.book.co.za/blog/2010/04/21/michael-cawood-green-wins-the-olive-schreiner-prize-for-prose-for-for-the-sake-of-silence/]
[[J. M. Coetzee]] writes, "Of the Trappist enterprise in nineteenth-century South Africa, with all its passionate personal rivalries and Byzantine internal politics, Michael Cawood Green has made a work of history cum fiction that will grip and sometimes amaze the reader."[https://web.archive.org/web/20110327123758/http://www.quartetbooks.co.uk/bookpages/forthesakeofsilence.html]
== References and Links == * [http://michaelcawoodgreen.co.uk Michael Green] * [http://www.northumbria.ac.uk/sd/academic/sass/about/humanities/englishhome/english_staff_list/m_green/ At Northumbria University]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100219234301/http://www.quartetbooks.co.uk/newtitles.html Quartet Books] * [http://www.literarytourism.co.za/ KwaZulu Natal Literary Tourism Project] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091026044841/http://www.monasteryteagarden.co.za/tours.html Mariannhill Tea Garden] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110714083149/http://michaelcawoodgreen.com/index_files/Page967.htm The Sunday Times] * TLS Review [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/tlskeywordsearch.tls?queryKeywords=michael+cawood+green&x=35&y=14]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Green, Michael Cawood}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:University of Natal alumni]] [[Category:South African male novelists]] [[Category:Historical fiction]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Ars.hussain|Ars.hussain]] ([[User talk:Ars.hussain|talk]]): Rv addition of inline external link.
revision.text:
A '''motorcycle rally''' is a gathering of [[motorcycling|motorcycle enthusiasts]]. Rallies can be large or small, and one-time or recurring. Some rallies are ride-in events, whereas some like the [[Iron Butt Association#Iron Butt Rally|Iron Butt Rally]] involve days of riding and an actual gathering only at the end of the ride.
==North America== [[File:Street lined with motorcycles at a motorcycle rally in Marietta, Ohio.jpg|thumb|Street lined with motorcycles at a motorcycle rally in [[Marietta, Ohio]].]] Notable annual [[North America]]n rallies with attendance in the hundreds of thousands from all over the continent include the [[Sturgis Motorcycle Rally]], [[Laconia Motorcycle Week]], [[Black Bike Week]] and [[Daytona Beach Bike Week]]. The [[Republic of Texas Biker Rally]] is held each June in Austin, Texas and attracts over 200,000 bikers to the state capitol. There are innumerable smaller, regional rallies around the United States, including the annual [[BMW MOA]] international rally, the [[Oyster Run]] in the Pacific Northwest, the [[Golden Aspen Rally]] (formerly Aspencade) in the Southwest, the [[Laughlin River Run]] in the West, [[Americade]] in the Northeast, and [[Indianapolis motorcycle Grand Prix#Motorcycles on Meridian|Motorcycles on Meridian]] in the Midwest. A popular rally in the East takes place in the mountains of Maryland, Apple's East Coast Motorcycle Rally (formerly East Coast Sturgis) is best known for its "old school" feel, beautiful mountain riding and even a Motorcycle Demolition Derby.
Rallies will often incorporate entertainment such as a [[Burnout (vehicle)|burnout]] pit, motorcycle contests, bike washes, [[motorcycle stunt riding|motorcycle stunt]] performances like [[wheelie]] acts and the [[wall of death (motorcycle act)|wall of death]], live bands, and [[dice run]]s or [[poker run]]s. The Indianapolis and Daytona Beach motorcycle rallies have championship motorcycle racing at nearby circuits. In some cases, rallies are held as benefits for organizations or groups such as the [[American Red Cross]], [[American Cancer Society]], [[American Legion]] or [[VFW]].
==Europe== The longest established motorcycle rally in Europe is the [[Elephant Rally|''Elefantentreffen'']] (Elephant Rally), established in 1956<ref name=current>{{citation|url=http://current.com/entertainment/comedy/88922655_the-coldest-meeting-elefantentreffen.htm|title=The coldest meeting -- Elefantentreffen|publisher=[[Current TV]]|date=April 2008}}</ref> by former Wehrmacht motorcyclists and named in honour of the [[Zündapp]] motorcycle that was nicknamed the "green elephant." The growing reputation of the Elephant Rally led to the creation in 1962 of a British winter rally, the [[Dragon rally]], held each February in North Wales.
One of the largest motorcycle rallies in Europe is the [[Thundersprint]], held annually in May in [[Northwich]], [[Cheshire]], [[England]] and usually has notable motorcycle champions or enthusiasts such as [[Giacomo Agostini]] and [[James May]]. Another large motorcycle rally is [http://glemseck101.de/ Glemseck 101]. It takes place around the Glemseck at the [[Solitude race track]] in [[Leonberg]], [[Germany]] every first weekend in September. A special attraction are the 1/8 mile drag races, where customizers and motorcycle brands send their best bikes and bikers to the race (e.g. [http://www.triumphmotorcycles.at/news-and-events/events/germany/2016/september/glemseck%20101 Triumph], [http://brand.bmw-motorrad.com/en/stories/events/glemseck-101.html BMW], [https://www.yamaha-motor.eu/baltic/products/motorcycles/sport-heritage/yard-built/glemseck/index.aspx Yamaha], [https://news.suzuki.de/essenza-sprint-glemseck-am-3-9-2016-vorstellung-sv650-little-bastard/ Suzuki]).
In the UK, the [[Iron Ore Rally]] is held annually in Egremont Cumbria and the [[Rally of Discovery]] is held in Ireland. Rallies are held all year round. Many motorcyclists (or bikers) prefer the winter rallies, such as the Mayflower MCCs [[Force Ten Rally]] or the Dean Vally MCCs [[Rallymans Rally]]. The usual order of the day is camping with a real ale tent and music. Rallies usually start on a Friday afternoon and finish at lunchtime on a Sunday. The point is to travel there by motorcycle, motorcycle and sidecar or trike (not cars or vans), meet friends from all over the country and sometimes further afield, claim a rally badge and enjoy the entertainment. Prizes are awarded for the furthest distance travelled, best bike, best [[rat bike]], oldest person attending, youngest person attending, etc. There are usually planned ride-outs on the Saturday taking in good roads and sometimes historic sites, museums, etc.
In the UK many people relate motorcycle rallies to the famous [[Bulldog Bash]] near Stratford-upon-Avon. This is a hugely popular event and attracts thousands of people including non-motorcyclists. There are many much smaller rallies that attract between 50 and 500 bikers to each event, organised and controlled by a host club. Rallies are still attended by motorcyclists that have been going to rallies for up to 40 or 50 years. In the UK motorcycle rallies began in earnest in the early 1960s as young, mainly working class men and women (usually on the [[pillion]]) gained freedom by motorcycle ownership and set off around the country camping. Some went in groups or clubs and thus the rally was born. Many were [[Ton-up boy]]s, later [[Greaser (subculture)|Greasers]] and then Greebos.
==Gypsy tour== {{Refimprove section|date=July 2009}}
'''Gypsy tour''' is an American motorcycling term which originated before the 1920s; the term has been mostly but not entirely replaced by ''rally'' or ''run''. Gypsy tours were organized where groups of riders all over the country converged on a favorite destination. The term ''gypsy'' was used because the riders would travel long distances and often sleeping in tents around a campfire along the way much like the Hollywood stereotype [[Romani people|gypsies]].
One Australian newspaper referring to a Gypsy Tour rally from Melbourne to Sydney in 1927, stated - "The idea of a "gypsy tour" originated in America. There these tours are usually being organised simultaneously in different cities and towns, and routes all converging on one centre, where a great rally is held by the touring parties".<ref>{{citation|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=December 29, 1927|page=9}}</ref> The term gypsy tour has been used for other activities, but predominantly motorcycle rallies, and the idea quickly spread around the world.
Many gypsy tours have been held over the years and are still a regular event for many vintage and modern motorcycle groups. The annual gypsy tour to [[Laconia, New Hampshire]] near [[Lake Winnipesaukee]] began in 1916 and is the oldest continuous motorcycle event in the U.S.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JFuwEgYzpGUC&pg=PA9&dq=gypsy+tour+motorcycle|title=Laconia Motorcycle Week|isbn=978-0-7385-5473-0|author=Charlie St. Clair |author2=Jennifer Anderson|year=2008|publisher=Arcadia Publishing}}</ref>
==Australia== A number of rallies are held throughout Australia, at all times of the year. These range from 'back to basics' rallies, usually held in remote locations with no facilities, to catered rallies held in country towns and other rural locations. Many rallies are held at a local recreation reserve, football ground, racecourse or showground in country towns. These venues often have toilet/shower blocks, and bar/kitchen facilities. Often the motorcycle club organising the rally will arrange for a local service group like the Rotary club, or local sporting club to cater an evening meal and breakfast, and to run the bar. These events often provide much needed revenue sources for the communities in which the rallies are held, and the communities welcome the rallies to their towns.
Compared to European and American rallies, Australian rallies are often small affairs, with attendance ranging from a few dozen to a few hundred bikes.
The [[Ulysses Club]] Annual General Meeting Event is a weeklong affair that brings in thousands of motorcyclists and millions of dollars to its host site, which can be different each year.<ref>{{citation|title=Ulysses Club National AGM|publisher=Tourism Central Australia|url=http://www.discovercentralaustralia.com/index.php/event-s/events-calendar/event/299-ulysses-club-national-agm|accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref> The 2014 event in [[Alice Springs]] is expected to draw 5,000 to 7,000 participants.<ref>{{citation|title=The A'vans are coming|date=October 10, 2011 |newspaper=Alice Spring News |publisher=Media Choice|location=Alice Springs, Australia|url=http://www.alicespringsnews.com.au/2011/10/10/1881/|accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref>
==New Zealand== There are number of rallies held throughout New Zealand, most events taking place over the warmer months. There are a couple of cold weather rallies such as the [[Brass Monkey Motorcycle Rally]].
==See also== * [[Biker bar]] *[[Long-distance motorcycle riding]]
==References== {{reflist}}

WIKIPEDIA | | IS NOT A COLLECTION OF LINKS NOR SHOULD IT BE USED FOR ADVERTISING. | | | | Excessive or inappropriate links WILL BE DELETED. | | See [[Wikipedia:External links]] & [[Wikipedia:Spam]] for details. | | | | If there are already plentiful links, please propose additions or | | replacements on this article's discussion page, or submit your link | | to the relevant category at the Open Directory Project (dmoz.org) | | and link back to that category using the {{dmoz}} template. | =======================({{No More Links}})=============================-->

'''Mundo Lingo''' are free language social events that happen independently in various metropolises in different countries.<ref>{{cite news |author=Fossati, Magica |title= There's a monthly global event where you can learn new languages - free |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/yourlanguage/italian/en/article/2017/01/13/theres-monthly-global-event-where-you-can-learn-new-languages-free |date=17 Aug 2017 |access-date=5 November 2017 |deadurl=no }}</ref> They usually take place in the late evening during the week (7pm to midnight) in a specific bar. They gather many men and women of all ages and all nationalities that wish to learn or improve one or more languages.<ref>{{cite news |author=unknown |title= ‘Mundo Lingo’ Language Exchange Social |url=http://www.barcelonaconnect.com/event/mundo-lingo-language-exchange-social/ |date= Jan 2016 |access-date=5 November 2017 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==Principle==
Each participant receive flags to stick to his clothes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://ici.radio-canada.ca/emissions/c_est_pas_trop_tot/2013-2014/chronique.asp?idChronique=360469 |title= Intégrer le Montréal multilingue |author=Lavoie, Hugo |date= 15 January 2015 |website= radio-canada.ca |access-date= 5 November 2017|language = french}}</ref> They are supposed to indicate their native language at the top, and the rest below (generally the languages they mastered and below the one they wants to learn). Then, people are free to chat with each other while having drinks.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mundolingo.org/about |title= About Mundo Lingo|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= 2017|website= mundolingo.org |access-date= 5 November 2017}}</ref>
==History==
The first Mundo Lingo event was an initiative of UK born Benji Moreira when he was an immigrant in [[Buenos Aires]] ([[Argentina]]). It took place on July 7, 2011 and was aimed for local Argentines to learn foreign languages and for internationals to practice Spanish. After a while, around 50 people per week were attending and the flag system was introduced. In 2014 the event grew increasingly popular and was exported to Cologne, London, Montreal, and then Melbourne.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mundolingo.org/history |title= History of Mundo Lingo|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= 2016|website= mundolingo.org |access-date= 5 November 2017}}</ref>
==Cities==
As of September 2018, Mundo Lingo events regularly take place in up to 30 cities, 24 countries and 5 continents.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mundolingo.org/navigation/cities |title= Mundo Lingo Cities|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= 2017|website= mundolingo.org | access-date = 17 September 2018}}</ref>
===Asia=== As of September 2018, Mundo Lingo events regularly take place in [[Saigon]] and [[Hanoi]] ([[Vietnam]]), [[Bangkok]] and [[Chiang Mai]] ([[Thailand]]), [[Nanjing]] ([[China]]), [[Osaka]] ([[Japan]]), [[Singapore]] and [[Yangon]] ([[Myanmar]]) .
===Oceania=== As of September 2018, Mundo Lingo events regularly take place in [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]] and [[Brisbane]] ([[Australia]]) and [[Wellington]] and [[Auckland]] ([[New Zealand]]).
===Europe=== As of September 2018, Mundo Lingo events regularly take place in [[Barcelona]] ([[Spain]]), [[Cologne]], [[Stuttgart]] and [[Munich]] ([[Germany]]), [[Copenhagen]] ([[Denmark]]), [[Geneva]] ([[Switzerland]]), [[London]] ([[England]]), [[Paris]] ([[France]]) and [[Oslo]] ([[Norway]]).
===America=== As of September 2018, Mundo Lingo events regularly take place in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Córdoba, Argentina|Córdoba]] and [[La Plata]] ([[Argentina]]), [[Lima]] ([[Peru]]), [[Rio de Janeiro]] ([[Brazil]]), [[Montréal]] and [[Toronto]] ([[Canada]]), [[New York City|New York]] ([[United States]]).
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://mundolingo.org Mundo Lingo]
[[Category:Language acquisition]] [[Category:Social events]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=September 2014}} '''National Science Week''' refers to series of science-related events for the general public which are held in a specific countries during a designated week of the year. The aim of such science weeks is to engage and inspire people of all ages with science, engineering and technology.
==Australia== [[Australia's]] National Science Week is held annually in August, funded through the Department of Industry, Innovation and Science. National Science Week welcomes an audience of over a million and hosts more than 1000 events across the nation. Science Week provides an opportunity for all Australians to participate in events and activities that showcase science and encourages younger people to consider continuing studies in science. Past participants have included polar explorer and environmental scientist [[Tim Jarvis]], NASA Astronaut [[Katherine Megan McArthur]]; environmentalist Tanya Ha; theoretical physicist [[Lawrence Krauss]]; and palaeontologist [[Scott Sampson]]. Another key activity during National Science Week is the National Project, which is run in conjunction with [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC Australia]]. Past project have included Weather Detective in 2014 and the Aussie Star Hunt in 2009. Also in 2009 [[Cosmos Magazine]] launched a website called [[HELLO FROM EARTH]] which collected over 28,000 messages which were beamed to the first Earth like planet candidate, [[Gliese 581d]]. In 2016 it included Wikibomb2016, a project to create missing Wikipedia pages on Australian women scientists.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in STEM Wikibomb|url=http://www.scienceweek.net.au/women-in-stem-wikibomb/|publisher=National Science Week (Australia)|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref>
==India== In [[India]], Science Week culminates in National Science Day, which takes place each year on 28 February to commemorate [[C. V. Raman]]'s discovery of the [[Raman scattering|Raman Effect]].
==United Kingdom== [[UK|Britain's]] National Science Week was first held in 1994. It is now known as ''[https://www.britishscienceweek.org/ British Science Week]'' and is one of the largest national celebrations of science. It is organised by the [[British Science Association]] and funded by BEIS (UK Department for Business, Energy, Innovation and Skills) and other partners. British Science Week is a massive UK-wide grassroots celebration of science which saw over 1 million people taking part in over 2,300 events and activities throughout the UK in 2017.
==United States== In the [[United States]], the National Science & Technology Week was one of the [[National Science Foundation]]'s main outreach efforts between 1985 and 1999, before the program was succeeded by ''Find Out Why'', a year-long outreach effort focused on families, offering everyday science activities. The idea was revisited in 2005 by the [[U.S. Department of Education]] and the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]], in collaboration with other government and scientific partners, with an "Excellence in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Education (ESTEME) Week."
==Other countries== Other national science weeks include the [[Norway|Norwegian]] Forskningsdagene ("Research Days"), the [[Science Week in Catalonia]], [[Canada]]'s National Science & Technology Week, Science Week in [[Ireland]]<ref>http://www.sfi.ie/engagement/science-week/</ref>, the [[South Africa]]n National Science Week, and [[China]]'s National Science Week launched in May 2006. On an international level, the [[European Union]] has held union-wide science weeks between 2000 and 2006.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{wikisource|Category:National Science Week}} *[http://www.scienceweek.net.au/ Australia's National Science Week] *[http://www.nsew.org.uk/ The UK's National Science and Engineering Week] *[http://www.britishscienceassociation.org/ British Science Association] *[http://www.science.gc.ca/nstw Canada's National Science & Technology Week] *[http://english.gov.cn/2006-05/21/content_287055.htm China's National Science Week] *[http://www.cordis.lu/scienceweek/home.htm European Science Week] *[http://www.hindu.com/2005/02/22/stories/2005022208020300.htm Indian Science Week and Science Day] *[http://www.forskningsdagene.no/index.html Forskningsdagene (Norway)] *[http://www.saasta.ac.za/programmes/focus-weeks/national-science-week/ South Africa's National Science Week] *[http://www.thebigbangfair.co.uk/ The Big Bang - UK Young Scientists & Engineers Fair] *[https://www.nsf.gov/od/lpa/nstw/ United States' National Science & Technology Week] *[http://www.esteme.org/About_ESTEME/index.html U.S. Excellence in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Education (ESTEME) Week 2005] *[http://www.ScienceWeek.ie Science Week Ireland] *[http://www.fundaciorecerca.cat/setmanaciencia Science Week in Catalonia] [[Category:Science festivals]] [[Category:Awareness weeks]] [[Category:February observances]] [[Category:March observances]] [[Category:August observances]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Festival | name = Pennine Film Festival | logo = Pennine Film Festival logo since 2015.png | image = Pennine_Film_Fesitval_collage.jpg | caption = Pennine Film Festival collage | status = Active | genre = [[film festival]] | date = May 6th – 8th 2016 | frequency = Annually | venue = Various, across Lancashire | location = Accrington, Lancashire | country = UK | website = http://www.penninefilm.com }}
The '''Pennine Film Festival''' is an annual festival started in 2006 focusing on independent filmmaking, offering local and national premieres, hosting masterclasses, workshops and discussions for filmmakers from the enthusiast to the professional.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pennine Film Festival|url=https://penninefilm.com|website=Pennine Film Festival Official Website}}</ref> The Film Festival is an established exhibitor and all-round film education resource for the growing independent film movement in England's North West region.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pennine Film Festival on Film Freeway.|url=http://filmfreeway.com/festival/PennineFilmFestival|website=Film Freeway}}</ref>
==History== The Pennine Film Festival was founded initially as a local student film competition hosted at [[Accrington & Rossendale College]] In 2006;<ref>{{cite web|title=Classic Ghostbusters hit movie will be shown in churchyard as part of Accrington film festival|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/hyndburn/11536769.Classic_Ghostbusters_hit_movie_will_be_shown_in_churchyard_as_part_of_Accrington_film_festival/|website=Lancashire Telegraph}}</ref> over the past decade the competition received a significant amount of entries, and consequently developing into a larger festival holding events outside the college campus.
==Format== The Pennine Film Festival is held annually between March and May every year. It primarily takes place in [[Lancashire]] across various venues within the county. These include cinemas, outdoor public spaces, galleries and theatres, offering filmmakers an opportunity to see their films on a big screen and to network with other creatives.
==Previous Events== In recent years, the festival offered events to compliment a screening of a [[feature film]], most commonly a Q&A with a filmmaker or an expert within the field of the films theme. Previous speakers include [[Get Carter]] director [[Mike Hodges]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Director Mike Hodges to make special appearance in Accrington|url=http://www.accringtonobserver.co.uk/news/local-news/director-mike-hodges-make-special-8568349|website=Accrington Observer}}</ref> The Pennine Film Festival also contributed to the Accrington Food & Drink Festival with an evening screening of the award-winning [[Sideways]] with a selection of [[wine]] and [[cheese]] tasting at The Ballroom at [[Accrington]] Town Hall.<ref>{{cite web|title=June 06, 2015 at The Ballroom at Accrington Town Hall in Accrington.|url=http://englandevents.co.uk/accrington-screening-of-sideways-with-wine-and-cheese/235486|website=England Events|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428114529/http://englandevents.co.uk/accrington-screening-of-sideways-with-wine-and-cheese/235486|archivedate=April 28, 2016|df=}}</ref> Previous participants also include directors [[Alex Cox]], [[Chris Bernard]], [[Phil Hawkins]] and actors [[Lee Ingleby]] and [[Margi Clarke]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Creative Media Production Level 3 BTEC Extended Diploma at Accrington and Rossendale College.|url=https://www.ucasprogress.com/course/1932779/creative-media-production-level-3-btec-extended-diploma|website=UCAS Progress}}</ref>
==Call for Entries== The Pennine Film Festival uses the FilmFreeway platform and is open for entries immediately after the end of the current running festival, welcoming film submissions from emerging and established filmmakers from around the world. Pennine accepts films with a maximum running time of 30 minutes awarding the best submitted film in various categories including: [[animation]], [[documentary]], [[narrative]], local, [[horror film|horror]] and [[student]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Pennine Film Festival on Film Freeway.|url=http://www.filmfreeway.com/festival/PennineFilmFestival|website=Film Freeway}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.penninefilm.com Pennine Film Festival Website] *[https://filmfreeway.com/festival/PennineFilmFestival Submissions Website]
[[Category:Film festivals in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Festivals in Lancashire]] [[Category:Short film festivals]]

{{use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Prager Zeitung | logo = | image = | caption = | type = [[Weekly newspaper]] | format = | owners = | founder = | publisher = Prago Media | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | foundation = {{start date and age|1991}} | political = [[Liberalism|Liberal]] | language = [[German language|German]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Prague]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = }}
The '''''Prager Zeitung''''' is a [[German language|German]] newspaper in the [[Czech Republic]] issued weekly in [[Prague]].
==History and profile== ''Prager Zeitung'' was founded in 1991.<ref name=et>{{cite web|title=Prager Zeitung|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=36370|work=Eurotopics|accessdate=13 December 2013}}</ref> It considers itself as a successor of the ''[[Prager Tagblatt]]'', a German-language daily in [[Bohemia]] published from 1876 to 1939.<ref name=et/>
''Prager Zeitung'', published by Prago Media spol, is an independent publication and has a liberal political leaning.<ref name=et/> It provides political news and puts special emphasis on the relations between the Czech Republic and its German-speaking neighbors.<ref name=et/> Its former editors include [[Egon Erwin Kisch]] and [[Max Brod]].<ref name=et/>
The weekly is also distributed in [[Germany]], [[Austria]] and [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Prager Zeitungon|url=http://www.snopes.com/politics/soapbox/pragerzeitungon.asp|work=Snopes|accessdate=13 December 2013|date=12 November 2012}}</ref> It is the largest non-Czech newspaper published in the Czech Republic.
==See also== * [[Germans in the Czech Republic]] * [[Deutsche Schule Prag]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.pragerzeitung.cz Prager Zeitung online]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Prager Zeitung}} [[Category:1991 establishments in Czechoslovakia]] [[Category:German diaspora in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Publications established in 1991]] [[Category:Newspapers published in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:German-language newspapers]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Prague]]

'''Random Hacks of Kindness''' ('''RHoK''') is a global community of technologists dedicated to solving problems for charities, non-profits and social enterprises by organising recurring [[Hackathon]]<nowiki/>s <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rhokaustralia.org/#rhok-home|title=Random Hacks of Kindness Australia Homepage|last=|first=|date=|website=Random Hacks of Kindness|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> that has existed since 2009. The organisation currently has a presence in over 20 cities throughout 5 continents, and had 2000 participants in 2017 <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1o1DbAEi9tKI4duEjognV1V4Zy0YjxZmN/view|title=2017 Random Hacks of Kindness Year in Review|last=|first=|date=|work=Google Docs|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref>.
== History == === Origins === Random Hacks of Kindness grew out of an industry panel discussion<ref name="rhok.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/about/what-is-random-hacks-of-kindness/ |title=What is Random Hacks of Kindness? « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> at the first [[Crisis camp]] Bar Camp in Washington, DC in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crisiscamp.eventbrite.com/ |title=Crisis Camp - Crisiscamp - Web 2.0- Eventbrite |publisher=Crisiscamp.eventbrite.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> Panel attendees included Patrick Svenburg<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crisiscampdc.ning.com/profile/svenburg?xg_source=profiles_memberList |title=Patrick Svenburg's Page - CrisisCampDC |publisher=Crisiscampdc.ning.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> of Microsoft, Phil Dixon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crisiscampdc.ning.com/profile/PhilDixon |title=Phil Dixon's Page - CrisisCampDC |publisher=Crisiscampdc.ning.com |date=2009-06-15 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> and Jeff Martin<ref>http://crisiscampdc.ning.com/profile/JefferyMartin</ref> of Google and Jeremy Johnstone<ref>[http://crisiscampdc.ning.com/main/search/search?q=jeremy+johnstone Crisiscampdc.ning.com]</ref> of Yahoo. They agreed to use their developer communities to create solutions that will affect disaster response, risk reduction and recovery.<ref>{{cite web|author="" |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yGr1IzzrF4I |title=A History of RHoK |publisher=YouTube |date=2010-12-03 |accessdate=2010-12-23}}</ref> The idea was for a "[[hackathon]]" with developers producing open source solutions. The World Bank's Disaster Risk Reduction Unit (Stuart Gill) and NASA's Open Government team (Robbie Schingler) joined the partnership and these "founding partners" (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, NASA and the World Bank)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/about |title=What is Random Hacks of Kindness? « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> decided on the name "Random Hacks of Kindness" for their first event.
An innovation incubator in the area of sustainable development, SecondMuse<ref>[http://www.secondmuse.com secondmuse.com]</ref> acts as "operational lead" for Random Hacks of Kindness,<ref name="rhok.org"/> coordinating global volunteer efforts, facilitating [[collaborative partnerships]], and managing communications and branding.
=== 2009: RHoK 0 ===
The first Random Hacks of Kindness (RHoK 0)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/events/rhok-0/ |title=RHoK #0 « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> was held at the [[Hacker Dojo]] in Mountain View, California in November 2009.<ref>{{cite web|author="" |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kd0vFbgWV-k&feature=related |title=RHoK at the Hacker Dojo |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-11-13 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emergencymgmt.com/disaster/Hackers-Unite-in-the-Name-of-Disaster-Preparedness.html |title=Hackers Unite in the Name of Disaster Preparedness |publisher=Emergencymgmt.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.worldbank.org/insidetheweb/node/519 |title=Random Hacks of Kindness support disaster relief projects | The intersection of the web and the World Bank |publisher=Blogs.worldbank.org |date=2009-11-30 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]] Administrator [[Craig Fugate]] gave the keynote<ref name="fema.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/newsrelease.fema?id=49939|title=FEMA: FEMA Administrator Craig Fugate Keynotes Random Hacks Of Kindness, Disaster Relief Codejam|date=2009-11-13|publisher=Fema.gov|accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> and made a call to action to the developers to apply their creativity to the challenges and featured hacks. The first RHoK event is known as RHoK 0 after 0-based array indexing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xw2k.nist.gov/dads/html/zeroBasedIndexing.html |title=0-based indexing |publisher=Xw2k.nist.gov |date=2006-07-06 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> in computer programming.
Featured projects were<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/projects/rhok-0/ |title=RHoK #0 « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> * I'm OK * Tweak the Tweet (not a code "hack", but an edit/republish "hack")<!-- what does that mean in plain English? --><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/projects/rhok-0/tweak-the-tweet/ |title=Tweak the Tweet « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> * Break Glass
Tweak the Tweet was used during the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|Haiti earthquake]] response in January 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epic.cs.colorado.edu/tweak-the-tweet/helping_haiti_tweak_the_twe.html |title=Project EPIC: Helping Haiti/Tweak the Tweet |publisher=Epic.cs.colorado.edu |date=2010-01-18 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref>
=== 2010: RHoK 1.0 and 2.0 === The second RHoK event was held at the Microsoft Chevy Chase offices in Washington DC on June 4–6, 2010.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/events/rhok-1-0/ |title=RHoK #1 « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/randomhacks/sets/72157624091261377/ |title=Washington, D.C. - a set on Flickr |publisher=Flickr.com |date=2010-06-06 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Public Sector DPE Team |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/publicsector/archive/2010/05/25/you-re-invited-to-be-a-part-of-the-random-hacks-of-kindness-hackathon-june-4-6-washington-dc.aspx |title=You’re Invited to be a part of the Random Hacks of Kindness “Hackathon” - June 4–6, Washington DC - Public Sector Developer Weblog - Site Home - MSDN Blogs |publisher=Blogs.msdn.com |date=2010-05-25 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rhokdc.eventbrite.com/ |title=Random Hacks of Kindness DC - World Bank - Microsoft- Eventbrite |publisher=Rhokdc.eventbrite.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> Crisis Commons hosted a Crisis Camp co-located.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.crisiscommons.org/wiki/Random_Hacks_of_Kindness_2010 |title=Random Hacks of Kindness 2010 - CrisisCommons Wiki |publisher=Wiki.crisiscommons.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> The reception for RHoK 1.0 was held at the US State Department, and was blogged by [[Aneesh Chopra]], the United States Chief Technology Officer.<ref name="whitehouse.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/06/03/hacking-humanity|title="Hacking for Humanity" | The White House|author=Aneesh Chopra|date=2010-06-03|publisher=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref>
While the Washington, DC RHoK was the "main stage", several other locations hosted satellite events at the same time,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> including Oxford England, Jakarta Indonesia, Sydney Australia, Nairobi Kenya, São Paulo Brazil, and Santiago Chile.fd
The "winning" hack at the Washington DC event was a new interface on CHASM (Combined Hydrology and Stability Model),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chasm.info/ |title=CHASM Software - Combined Hydrology & Slope Stability Model |publisher=Chasm.info |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/2010/06/rhok-1-0-washington-d-c-winning-hack-chasm/ |title=RHoK #1.0 Washington D.C. Winning Hack: CHASM « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date=2010-06-11 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> a system to make landslide predictions. CHASM continues to be developed and is supported by groups including the World Bank.<ref name="web.worldbank.org">{{cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/NEWS/0,,contentMDK:22776384~pagePK:34370~piPK:34424~theSitePK:4607,00.html?cid=EXT_TwitterWBPubs_P_EXT |title=News & Broadcast - Google, Microsoft, Yahoo!, Nasa And The World Bank Team Up With Hackers From Around The World To Meet The Challenge Of Disaster Risk Management |publisher=Web.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref>
The third Random Hacks of Kindness was held on December 4 and 5, 2010, in 21 cities on 5 continents.<ref name="web.worldbank.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/events/rhok-2/ |title=RHoK #2 « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/2010/12/rhok-2-world-map/ |title=RHoK #2 World Map « RHoK |publisher=Rhok.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref>
=== 2011 - 2013: RHoK 3.0, 4.0 and 5.0 === The fourth Random Hacks of Kindness (RHoK 3.0) was held in 2011 in the cities of: Buenos Aires, Toronto, Nairobi, Lusaka, Bogota, San Pablo, Singapur, Tel Aviv, Birmingham, México DF, Juárez, Atlanta, Chicago, Nueva York, San Francisco and Seattle. The most active city to be participant was Buenos Aires, which was held in the Globant office and the participants included Guibert Englebienne (CTO of Globant) and Alejandro Pablo Tkachuk (ex-Globant and now CTO of Calculistik) <ref>http://www.apertura.com/historico/Hackear-para-ayudar-20110301-0011.html</ref>.
RHoK 3.0 was held twice in 2012: On the 3-4 June and again on the 1-2 December. This saw multiple cities come into play and a huge turnaround of developers from all over the world including Cape Town. The focus of the hackathon was toilets and/or sanitation.
The sixth global hackathon (RHoK 4.0) was also a major success. It was held twice in 2013 (in June and in December). UN Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] gave the keynote speech at New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhok.org/2010/12/in-a-weekend-you-can-change-the-world/ |publisher=RHoK.org |title=Blog post from RHoK.org with photos of UN Secretary General launching RHoK 2.0 in New York |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unglobalpulse.org/blog/un-secretary-general-appeals-global-open-source-community |publisher=UN Global Pulse |title=UN Secretary General Speaks at Random Hacks of Kindness Launch and appeals to global Open Source community |date= |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> Also speaking at NYC were NASA Deputy Administrator [[Lori Garver]], Google vice president for research [[Alfred Spector]], Microsoft Director Patrick Svenburg, Parsons The New School for Design Dean Joel Towers and [[UN Global Pulse]] director, Robert Kirkpatrick.
=== 2014 - 2016 === 2014 and 2015 saw the organisation shrink as the rhok.org website went down, cutting off global coordination<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/RandomHacks/posts/10153083474620465|title=Random Hacks of Kindness|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> and events in a number of cities ceased to be held. However, a new website was created at the end of 2016 at [https://rhok.cc rhok.cc]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/RandomHacks/posts/10153577566070465|title=Random Hacks of Kindness|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref>, and communities continued to thrive in multiple cities in India and Australia, as well as Ottawa and Berlin <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aFuMeqkXlp1c3DCdMtw663r4qeg7XBy8XMkiuaYcjQ0/edit|title=RHoK Global 2016 - Review|work=Google Docs|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref>. RHoK Jnr, an independent effort for students in the United States, also continued to thrive, holding 7 events in 2016<ref name=":1" />.
=== 2017 - 2018 === In 2017 rebuilding of the global community continued, and connections with all the active RHoK communities around the world were reestablished. The global community grow considerably, with events over 6 cities in Australia and 3 in India, as well as events in Ottawa, Berlin, Washington DC, Pretoria, and Ghana<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1o1DbAEi9tKI4duEjognV1V4Zy0YjxZmN/view|title=2017 Random Hacks of Kindness Year in Review|last=|first=|date=|work=Google Docs|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref>.
== Open source code == The Random Hacks of Kindness specifies that all contributions and code produced during RHoK hackathons must be released under an OSI approved open source license<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.rhok.org/Presenting_Projects_and_Problems#Code_and_Licenses |title=RHoK projects must use an OSI approved license |date= |accessdate=2010-12-09}}</ref> and be released in a public code repository. RHoK maintains [[GitHub]] repositories which contain code for many of the hacks.<ref>[https://github.com/RHoK Github.com]</ref>
==See also== * [[Geekcorps]] * [[Geeks Without Bounds]] * [[Information_and_communication_technologies_for_development|Information and communication technologies for development (ICT4D)]] * [[NetCorps]] * [[Peace Corps]] * [[Kofi_Annan#United_Nations_Information_Technology_Service_.28UNITeS.29|United Nations Information Technology Service (UNITeS)]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.rhok.cc Official website] * [https://rhokaustralia.org Official website - Australia] * [https://rhokindia.org Official website - India]

{{Infobox Election | election_name = Russian legislative election, 1990 | country = Russian SFSR | flag_year = | flag_image = | type = parliamentary | ongoing = no | party_colour = | previous_election = Russian legislative election, 1985 | previous_year = 1985 | next_election = Russian legislative election, 1993 | next_year = 1993 | seats_for_election = All 1068 seats to the
[[Congress of People's Deputies of Russia|Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian SFSR]] | election_date = {{Start date|1990|03|04}} | turnout =77% | image1 = [[File:Gorbachev (cropped).png|120px]] | colour1 = | nominee1 = | leader1 = [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] | party1 = Communist Party of the Soviet Union | leader_since1 = March 11, 1985 | home_state1 = | leaders_seat1 = | running_mate1 = | last_election1 = | seats_before1 = | seats_needed1 = | electoral_vote1 = | states_carried1 = | seats1 = 920 | seats_after1 = | seat_change1 = | popular_vote1 = | percentage1 = 86% | swing1 = | image2 = [[File:No image.svg|120px]] | colour2 = | nominee2 = | leader2 = | leader_since2 = | party2 = Independent (politician) | alliance2 = | home_state2 = | leaders_seat2 = | running_mate2 = | last_election2 = | seats_before2 = | seats_needed2 = | electoral_vote2 = | states_carried2 = | seats2 = 148 | seats_after2 = | seat_change2 = | popular_vote2 = | percentage2 = 14% | swing2 = | map_image = | map_size = | map_alt = | map = | map_caption = | title = [[Prime Minister of Russia|Prime Minister]] | posttitle = | before_election = [[Aleksandr Vlasov (politician)|Alexander Vlasov]] | before_colour = | after_election = [[Ivan Silayev]] | after_colour = | before_party = Communist Party of the Soviet Union | after_party = Communist Party of the Soviet Union | result = }} '''Legislative elections''' were held in the [[Russian SFSR]] on 4 March 1990. A total of 1,068 deputies were elected to the [[Congress of People's Deputies of Russia|Congress of People's Deputies of the RSFSR]] for a term of five years, 86% of them from the [[CPSU|Communist Party]],{{cite web |url=http://www.politika.su/gos/ndrs.html|title=Congress of People’s Deputies and the Supreme Soviet of RSFSR / Russian Federation|date=2008-03-03|work=Politika|language=ru}} the rest were [[non-partisan]]. Parties other than the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU) were not formally allowed to participate in the election, however the elections were [[Competitive election|competitive]] and the [[Democratic Russia]] movement, an organization uniting many opposition political groups, won about 190 seats. The elected Congress began its first session on 16 May. Among the elected deputies from the CPSU was [[Boris Yeltsin]], who was then elected by the Congress as Chairman of the Supreme Soviet of RSFSR, effectively the leader of Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.gorby.ru/rubrs.asp?art_id=15056&rubr_id=175&page=5|title=Chronicle of Perestroika|date=2008-03-03|work=The Gorbachev Foundation|language=ru|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070502084319/http://www.gorby.ru/rubrs.asp?art_id=15056&rubr_id=175&page=5|archivedate=2007-05-02|df=}} Many CPSU members, including Yeltsin, subsequently resigned from the CPSU. The CPSU was temporarily banned by Yeltsin in August 1991 in the aftermath of the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|August Coup]], and the CPSU, along with the [[Soviet Union]], collapsed completely by December of the same year. It was the first and only [[free election]] to the Congress of People's Deputies of the RSFSR. It became the [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian Federation]] after the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], and was dissolved by Yeltsin in October 1993 during the [[Russian constitutional crisis of 1993]] and replaced by the [[Federal Assembly of Russia]]. ==Results== [[Image:Russian Congressional Parties 1990.png|thumb|right|Initial composition of the Congress]] {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan=2 style="background-color:#E9E9E9" align=left|Parties and coalitions !style="background-color:#E9E9E9" align=right|% !style="background-color:#E9E9E9" align=right|Seats |- |align=left colspan=2|[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] |align="right" |86% |align="right" |920 |- |align=left colspan=2|Independents |align="right" |14% |align="right" |148 |- |align=left colspan=2 style="background-color:#E9E9E9"|'''Total (turnout 77%)'''{{cite web |url=http://socarchive.narod.ru/bibl/polros/Altay_r/elecstat-alr.html |title=Electoral statistics|date=2008-03-03|work=Society.ru |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040127221945/http://socarchive.narod.ru/bibl/polros/Altay_r/elecstat-alr.html |archivedate = 2004-01-27|language=ru}} ([[Internet Archive]] backup) !style="background-color:#E9E9E9" align=right|'''100%''' !style="background-color:#E9E9E9" align=right|'''1068''' |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Russian elections}} {{Soviet elections}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Russian Legislative Election, 1990}} [[Category:1990 elections in Russia]] [[Category:Legislative elections in Russia|1990]] [[Category:Perestroika]] [[Category:March 1990 events in Europe]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = SABIA-Mar 1 / SAC-E<!--defaults to page title--> | names_list = SABIA-Mar (Brazil) SAC-E (Argentina)<!--list of previous names if the spacecraft has been renamed. Include the dates applicable if possible, and separate each name with a linebreak. Omit if the spacecraft has only ever been known by one name. Do not include Harvard, COSPAR/NSSDC or SATCAT/NORAD/NASA designations as alternative names-->
<!--image of the spacecraft/mission--> | image = Satélites SABIA-Mar 1 y SABIA-Mar 2.jpg | image_caption = SABIA-Mar 1 (left) and SABIA-Mar 2 (right) | image_alt = <!--image alt text--> | image_size = <!--include px/em; defaults to 220px-->
<!--Basic details--> | mission_type = <!--eg. Technology, Reconnaissance, ISS assembly, etc--> | operator = [[National Institute for Space Research|INPE]] / [[CONAE]]<!--organisation(s) that operate(d) the spacecraft--> | Harvard_designation = <!--spacecraft launched 1962 and earlier only (eg. 1957 Alpha 2)--> | COSPAR_ID = <!--spacecraft launched since 1963 only (aka NSSDC ID; eg. 1998-067A)--> | SATCAT = <!--satellite catalogue number, omit leading zeroes (e.g. 25544)--> | website = [http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/espanol/misiones-satelitales/sac-e/descripcion-del-proyecto CONAE-SAC-E]<!--Homepage of the craft/mission, OFFICIAL PAGES ONLY--> | mission_duration = <!--How long the mission lasted--> | distance_travelled = <!--How far the spacecraft travelled (if known)--> | orbits_completed = <!--number of times the spacecraft orbited the Earth - see below for spacecraft beyond Earth orbit--> | suborbital_range = <!--downrange distance reached if spacecraft did not enter orbit--> | suborbital_apogee = <!--altitude reached if spacecraft did not enter orbit-->
<!--Spacecraft properties--> | spacecraft = <!--Spacecraft name/serial number (eg. Space Shuttle ''Discovery'', Apollo CM-118), etc--> | spacecraft_type = <!--eg. GPS Block II, Kobalt-M, US-K, etc--> | spacecraft_bus = <!--eg. A2100M, Star-2, etc--> | manufacturer = [[INVAP]]<!--company or companies who built the satellite--> | launch_mass = <!--fuelled mass at launch, not including rocket or upper stage--> | BOL_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit at beginning of operational life, after LEOP phase--> | landing_mass = <!--Mass after landing (recovered spacecraft only)--> | dry_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit without fuel--> | payload_mass = {{convert|680|kg|abbr=on}}<!--Mass of cargo carried by spacecraft (eg. for Space Shuttle), or total mass of instrumentation/equipment/experiments for mission--> | dimensions = {{convert|2|m|abbr=on}} ⌀ × {{convert|2.2|m|abbr=on}} height envelope<!--body dimensions and solar array span--> | power = <!--end-of-life power, in watts-->
<!--Launch details--> | launch_date = '''Planned:''' 2020<!--{{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|hh|mm|ss|TZ=Z}}--> | launch_rocket = <!--Rocket that launched the satellite, include upper stage if distinct from rocket* and if possible flight/tail/serial number--> | launch_site = <!--Where the rocket launched from, including complex and pad; do not include the full address or country--> | launch_contractor = <!--organisation(s) that conducted the launch (eg. United Launch Alliance, Arianespace, etc)--> | deployment_from = <!--place where deployed from--> | deployment_date = <!--date deployed--> | entered_service = <!--date on which the spacecraft entered service, if it did not do so immediately after launch--> <!-- * - e.g. Proton-M/Briz-M not Proton-M, but Titan IV(401)A not Titan IV(401)A-Centaur-->
<!--end of mission--> | disposal_type = <!--Whether the spacecraft was deorbited, decommissioned, placed in a graveyard orbit, etc--> | deactivated = <!--when craft was decommissioned--> | destroyed = <!--when craft was destroyed (if other than by re-entry)--> | last_contact = <!--when last signal received if not decommissioned--> | recovery_by = <!--recovered by--> | recovery_date = <!--recovery date--> | decay_date = <!--when craft re-entered the atmosphere, not needed if it landed--> | landing_date = <!--when the spacecraft made a controlled landing, not needed if it did not return intact--> | landing_site = <!--where the craft landed; site/runway or coordinates--> <!-- The following template should be used for ONE of the three above fields "end_of_mission", "decay" or "landing" if the spacecraft is no longer operational. If it landed intact, use it for the landing time, otherwise for the date it ceased operations, or the decay date if it was still operational when it re-entered. {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD|hh|mm|ss|TZ=Z}} (for Zulu/UTC) or {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD}} (if time unknown) -->
<!--orbit parameters--> <!--as science-related articles, SI units should be the principal units of measurement, however we usually use {{convert}} to display imperial units in parentheses after the initial values--> | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]]<!--geocentric, selenocentric, etc - please link (e.g. [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]])--> | orbit_regime = [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]]<!--high, low, medium, molniya, GSO - please link (e.g. [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] - please don't use acronyms--> | orbit_longitude = <!--geosynchronous satellites only--> | orbit_slot = <!--Designation of orbital position or slot, if not longitude (e.g plane and position of a GPS satellite)--> | orbit_semimajor = <!--semimajor axis--> | orbit_eccentricity = <!--orbital eccentricity--> | orbit_periapsis = 645 km<ref name=conae-phaseafinalreport /><!--periapsis altitude--> | orbit_apoapsis = 645 km<!--apoapsis altitude--> | orbit_inclination = <!--orbital inclination--> | orbit_period = <!--time taken to complete an orbit--> | orbit_RAAN = <!--right ascension of the ascending node--> | orbit_arg_periapsis = <!--argument of perigee/periapsis--> | orbit_mean_anomaly = <!--mean anomaly at epoch, only use in conjunction with an epoch value--> | orbit_mean_motion = <!--mean motion of the satellite, usually measured in orbits per day--> | orbit_repeat = <!--repeat interval/revisit time--> | orbit_velocity = <!--speed at which the spacecraft was travelling at epoch - only use for spacecraft with low orbital eccentricity--> | orbit_epoch = <!--the date at which the orbit parameters were correct--> | orbit_rev_number = <!--revolution number--> | apsis = gee<!--planet specific apsis term (eg. gee/helion/selene/etc - defaults to generic "apsis")-->
<!--Telescope parameters--> | instrument_type = <!--converts telescope fields to suit a camera or other similar instrument--> | telescope_name = <!--name, if different to the satellite--> | telescope_type = <!--type of telescope, mirror arrangement, etc--> | telescope_diameter = <!--diameter of telescope--> | telescope_focal_length= <!--focal length of telescope--> | telescope_area = <!--collecting area--> | telescope_wavelength = <!--wavelengths at which the telescope operates--> | telescope_resolution = <!--resolution of telescope--> | instruments = <!--a list of instruments on the satellite-->
<!--transponder parameters--> | trans_band = [[S band]] and [[X band]] (Downlink only)<!--Transponder frequency bands--> | trans_frequency = <!--specific frequencies--> | trans_bandwidth = <!--bandwidth--> | trans_capacity = <!--capacity of the transponders--> | trans_coverage = <!--area covered--> | trans_TWTA = <!--TWTA output power--> | trans_EIRP = <!--equivalent isotropic power--> | trans_HPBW = <!--half-power beam width-->
| instruments_list = <!-- start collapsible list of instruments --> {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments | acronym1 = VIS-NIR | name1 = Optical camera from [[Visible light|VISible]] to [[Near-infrared|NIR]] with 11 bands, from 412 nm to 865 nm.<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments /> | acronym2 = NIR-SWIR | name2 = Optical camera from [[Near-infrared|NIR]] to [[Short-wavelength infrared|SWIR]] with 6 bands, from 750 nm to 1,600 nm.<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments /> | acronym3 = DCS | name3 = Data Collection System<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments /> | acronym4 = TIR | name4 = [[Thermal infrared|Thermal InfraRed]] camera in two bands, 11 and 12 microns.<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments /> | acronym5 = MAC | name5 = Multi-Angle multispectral Camera with 5 bands, 4 multi angle and 1 panchromatic.<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments /> }}
<!--Only use where a spacecraft/mission is part of a clear programme of sequential missions. If in doubt, leave it out--> | programme = | previous_mission = | next_mission =
<!--mission insignia or patch--> | insignia = <!--omit the "file" prefix--> | insignia_caption = <!--image caption--> | insignia_alt = <!--image alt text--> | insignia_size = <!--include px/em; defaults to 180px--> }}
The '''SABIA-Mar''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: {{lang|es|'''S'''atélites '''A'''rgentino-'''B'''rasileño para '''I'''nformación '''A'''mbiental del '''Mar'''}}), originally called '''SAC-E''' by [[CONAE]] is a dual satellite joint [[Earth observation satellite|Earth observation]] mission. The mission objective is to study the oceanic biosphere, its changes along time and how it is affected and reacts to human activity.<ref name=conae-presentation20160210 /> It focuses on monitoring of ocean surfaces, especially studies of the ocean ecosystem, the carbon cycle, marine habitats, and mapping.<ref name=inpe-newsplanodiretormiolo /><ref name=ioccg-chamonsabiamar />
This collaboration between the Argentine (CONAE) and the Brazilian ([[Brazilian Space Agency|AEB]]) space agencies was originally supposed to make two identical spacecraft with Argentina supplying the payload and Brazil the satellite bus. The satellites, '''SABIA-Mar A''' and '''SABIA-Mar B''', are supposed to fly in 2017 and 2018, and be operated until 2021.<ref name=inpe-newsplanodiretormiolo /><ref name=ioccg-chamonsabiamar />
By 2016, CONAE announced that an agreement had been reached, where Argentina would make '''SABIA-Mar 1''', and Brazil would make '''SABIA-Mar 2'''. The Argentine satellite is supposed to fly in 2020.<ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarintroduction />
==SABIA-Mar 1== SABIA-Mar 1 will be designed and built by the Argentine technological company [[INVAP]]. They will act as prime contractor, integrator and will supply two instruments. It is expected to be launched in 2020, have a 5-year design life and fly on a [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] orbit with a four-day revisit frequency.<ref name=invap-sabiamar20160822 /> It successfully passed PDR on April 2016 which marked the end of Phase B development and the project thus entered Phase C, Detailed Design.<ref name=conaeesp-pr20160410 /> In April 2018, the Critical Design Review of the flight segment was approved.<ref name="conaecriticaldesignsegment">{{cite news|title=Otro Satélite Aprobado: Comienza la Fabricación de SABIA-Mar 1|url=http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/espanol/2018/1026-avances-mision-sabia-mar|accessdate=25 April 2018|agency=[[CONAE]]|date=25 April 2018|language=spanish}}</ref> ==SABIA-Mar 2== SABIA-Mar 2 will be built in Brazil on the [[Multi Mission Platform (satellite bus)|Multi Mission Platform]] the [[satellite bus]] developed for [[Amazônia-1]]. It will have a service module with a dry mass of {{convert|292|kg|abbr=on}} and a power budget of 304 Watts, and a payload module with a mass of {{convert|219|kg|abbr=on}} and a power budget of 260 Watts.<ref name=conae-phaseafinalreport />
==Instruments== Source:<ref name=ioccg-chamonsabiamar /> * Global House: [[Multispectral image|multispectral camera]] [[CCD camera]] with 1.1 km [[Sensor resolution|resolution]] * Regional Chamber: CCS multispectral camera with 200 m resolution * SST camera * Chamber of images to ground
==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[Brazilian space program]]
==References== {{Reflist|3|refs= <ref name=conae-phaseafinalreport>{{cite web |url=http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/english/component/docman/doc_download/130-phase-a-final-report.pdf |title=SABIA-MAR-Phase A Final Report (SB-010400-IA-00100-A) |publisher=[[CONAE]] |date=2013-11-19 |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=conae-presentation20160210>{{cite web |url=http://www.asi.it/sites/default/files/attach/pagina/04_workshop_capua_conae_hisas.pdf |title=CONAE National Space Program |date=February 10, 2016 |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=conaeesp-pr20160410>{{cite web |url=http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/espanol/component/rsevents/event/45-revision-preliminar-de-diseno-pdr-proyecto-sabia-mar |title=Revisión Preliminar de Diseño (PDR) Proyecto SABIA-Mar |trans-title=SABIA-Mar passes Preliminary Design Review (PDR) |date=April 2016 |publisher=[[CONAE]] |language=Spanish |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarinstruments>{{cite web |url=http://www.conae.gob.ar/index.php/espanol/instrumentos |title=Instrumentos |trans-title=Instruments |publisher=[[CONAE]] |language=Spanish |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=conaeesp-sabiamarintroduction>{{cite web |url=http://www.conae.gob.ar/index.php/espanol/introduccion-sace |title=Introducción |trans-title=Introduction |publisher=[[CONAE]] |language=Spanish |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=inpe-newsplanodiretormiolo>{{cite web |url=http://www.inpe.br/noticias/arquivos/pdf/Plano_diretor_miolo.pdf |title=Plano Diretor 2011 - 2015 |trans-title=General Plan 2011 - 2015 |publisher=[[National Institute for Space Research|INPE]] |language=Portuguese |accessdate=2014-03-06}}</ref> <ref name=invap-sabiamar20160822>{{cite web |url=http://www.invap.com.ar/es/espacial-y-gobierno/proyectos-espaciales/sabia-mar.html |title=SABIA-Mar |trans-title=SABIA-Mar |publisher=[[INVAP]] |language=Spanish |access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> <ref name=ioccg-chamonsabiamar>{{cite web|url=http://www.ioccg.org/sensors/Chamon_SABIA_MAR.pdf |title=The SIBIA_Mar Mission |publisher=Ioccg.org |accessdate=2014-03-06}}</ref> }}
